text: Any examples of very shocking undefined behavior?
People often comment that a program can legitimately respond to undefined behavior by deciding to reformat your hard drive.
However, in practice undefined behaviors in most languages do something rather unsurprising, for example:
I have yet to see a serious C++ compiler that responds to u = (u++); by reformatting the hard drive.
I also have yet to see a case where this assigned the value of u+2 to u, though this would only be a mildly surprising rather than shocking.
Can anyone offer real-world examples where the undefined behavior was incredibly shocking and/or weird?
